cons: 1. Higher layer is tight lipped about future of Bangalore center. Leaders at Bangalore have no clue about the future. Massive exodus of people from Bangalore center (either to the US or outside). Many talented folks have left the company to other companies in Bangalore. With the remaining beaten down, low-in-moral and tired people death of Bangalore center seems imminent.2. Performance Evaluation is done quarterl… y. This has created a lot of pressure among peers to outsmart others. Very unhealthy competition. In the wake when there is no meaningful work, people fight like dogs to take credit for what ever meager gets delivered from Bangalore3. Salary hikes and promotions have not happened for 70% of the people at Bangalore this year. Clear sign by management that "We don't want you. Please leave"
advice: Please be clear. If you don't want to keep the Bangalore center or just have it for support services to run during non-business hours of USA then please come out in the open and announce. Creating a situation that forces people to leave is not a sign of good leadership. You don't have to pay severance. People will graciously leave.
pros: 1. Use to have an excellent culture2. Amazing perks and pay3. Excellent quality of work
summary: Yahoo's Bangalore center is a gas chamber (This review is only for Bangalore center)

cons: * Poor management, for instance, you have non-technical and/or inexperienced managers leading teams of engineers. Middle managements block the flow of information from the top. Progress reports only go one way -- from the bottom to the top. You never know what your managers are doing.* Zero opportunity for promotion and recognition unless you suck up to the manager and he gives you a nice QPR rating. It doesn't m… atter how talented you are and what you contributed to the team. As long as you are a smooth talker and can kiss the manager's rear end, you're in good shape.* QPR leads to favoritism and low moral. Team mates are now competing against each other instead of collaborating and sharing ideas.* Repetitive weekly status update meetings. I thought Marissa told the entire org no status update meetings. You spend more time preparing for meetings than actually doing your work.* Low pay % increases - don't expect to get a salary increase for the hard work done.* Despite efforts to improve execution, decision making is still as slow as a crawling turtle.
advice: * Get rid of all the useless meetings* Get rid of the stack ranking system and do REAL performance reviews based on the quality of the work done and contribution to the org.* Allow individual contributors to anonymously rate their managers, either a pass or fail grade. If the manager fails, he gets demoted and the senior management must take action to find a suitable person that fits the role.
pros: * Free food* Above average compensation (but yearly increase % is minuscule), stock options, employee stock purchase plan, etc.* Free mobile phone* Commuters/gym benefits, etc.* Incredible technology stack (both software and hardware) to play with.
summary: Free food & excellent benefits, poor management and unfair reviews
